posts.title: Alternative Grants: Growing a Movement
posts.content:
When you start something new—plant a garden perhaps—you begin with fertile ground to grow your idea. Just like a seedling that needs water, sunlight and good energy to grow, a new project needs that same nurturing to come to life.

So, it was an especially proud moment this month when Alternative saw its new initiative Alternative Grants come to life and bearfruit in the form of a super fun launch party at its Abbot Kinney store in Venice.

Inspired by our brand values of Empowerment, Play and Impact, Alternative created the program to bring communities together to select grant recipients for neighborhood improvement projects; and for a kick-off event, we couldn’t have asked for a more charismatic crew to share in the excitement.

Hundreds of agriculture enthusiasts, Venice locals and friends of Alternative came by to mingle, meet renegade gardener and our host for the evening Ron Finley, plus cast their vote for the winner of our first Alternative Grant. Dart DJ set the musical tone while everyone sipped cocktails and coconut water, conversing about compost and how they’ve seen gardening change people’s lives.

“After I watched your TED talk, I planted a garden at home with my wife and our two kids… Now our kids have watering cans, we’re eating a lot healthier, and we’re going to start more gardening projects in our community, too,” Justin Milrad of Alternative told Ron Finley. “I love to hear that shit,” Finley replied with a big grin.

Our first Alternative Grant was inspired by Finley, a South Central Los Angeles-based renegade gardener who fights to transform “food deserts” into “food forests.” In partnership with Finley, Alternative asked the local Venice and westside community to propose gardening and urban agriculture projects they would like to see realized in Venice. 

Then, the five finalists were selected to share their projects at the party: Guacamole Gardens, Abundant Gardens, WE Gardens, Community-Supported Agriculture and Ocean-Friendly Gardens. After all five presentations were made and votes cast, WE Gardens was announced as the winner, a project focused on student gardens in school parking lots.Speaking on behalf of WE Gardens, Katie Laurie invited all of the finalists to work together and collaborate, since everyone shared the same passion.

Just as Alternative’s design director Orondava Mumford explained in his opening remarks, “we partner with people like Ron Finley because they inspire social change and empowerment. Because they inspire us, all of us.”

And that same warm and welcoming energy continued the entire evening, everyone inspired and enthusiastic about collaborating and creating positive change in their communities. You could feel it growing and blooming, right then and there, and you knew it was something you wanted to be a part of.

Shannon Flaherty Randall

Shop our new graphic tees benefitting the Ron Finley project to grow neighborhood gardens.

Many thanks to everyone who made the event a huge success: Imprint Projects, Newcastle, Bushmills, CocoLibre and more!

posts.title: Imaginary Authors
posts.content:
With a concept that taps into the haunting, evocative, and nostalgic properties of scent, Imaginary Authors is a collection of fragrances inspired by made up authors of the past. Many of them are familiar, even though they are imaginary. For instance, the scent The Soft Lawn with it’s 20′s era aesthetic, is said to have a whiff of tennis balls and clay courts and calls to mind F. Scott Fitzgerald.

The man behind the line Josh Meyers got his entry into this world through an interest in old-school shaving culture. Meeting a fellow enthusiast from Boston, he struck up an online friendship based on a shared love of art and The Ramones and their conversations lead to an introduction into the world of niche fragrances. Prior to this Josh had been decidedly anti-fragrance, finding all the mall brands to smell very much the same. He came to discover a world of fragrances that was totally new, strange and exciting.

His imagination on fire, he began ordering raw materials for some personal exploration…

“It started as a small project, it wasn’t like I was trying to create a perfume line or a job, it was just a project that I could do on my time off and it kinda just kept snowballing.”

Before he knew it he was deeper and deeper in and found himself in need of a web designer and some packaging to share his new creations. Starting with 13 concepts he narrowed it down to 7 which currently comprise the line.

Wanting the concept and marketing around the perfume to be accessible and to really describe what the perfumes actually smelled like, unlike a lot of mainstream naked-lady-in-a-field perfume ads, he spent a long time working with colors and image collages before collaborating with a designer and arriving at the Imaginary Authors concept. There was a quest for a “mythical element” that could be described which would act as a clue as to the deeper story of the scent. A series of stories and characters began to evolve. Every detail in terms of packaging and marketing was considered.

“It’s really important to me that the colors match with the perfume and give off a tone or a vibe.”

Scent is so evocative and leads enthusiasts to weave elaborate stories and create transporting descriptions.

“It’s kind of like talking about a painting that you can’t see and so you’re describing the blues and the greens and trying to describe the shapes. And it’s pretty fun…once you connect on this fragrance level it’s like meeting someone without being able to see them. It’s a very cool connection. When someone likes my stuff it’s just mind-blowing, especially when someones really resonating with it.”

Talking about scent and it’s power to bring up vivid memories Josh describes his earliest scent memory…

“When I was a little kid we lived in California for five years and now if I smell linden it takes me right back (snapping his fingers). Oh my gosh, it just floods me with memories of being a four year old on a little tricycle.”

When asked about plans, dreams, and aspirations for the future of Imaginary Authors Josh says “I’ve only been doing this for a short while but I love it. I just absolutely love it. And I really want to keep doing it so that’s pretty much my only goal.”

Bria Phillips

posts.title: The Giving Kitchen Initiative
posts.content:
Last time we met up with the Hidingers, we talked about their farm-to-table supper club, Staplehouse, based out of their Atlanta home. This time, our talk was about setting goals and their latest project, The Giving Kitchen Initiative.

Ryan: Some things have changed since we last talked. December 21st we had the cancer diagnosis which was really difficult, but we were, pretty quickly, thanks to the spirit of our community and our close friends and family and everyone rallying able to turn it into something really cool and positive. Its not that it makes any less of a day to day struggle, its certainly tough, but we’ve got new vision now, new spirit, and focus.

We’ve had a lot of progress with the cancer itself, the treatment that we’re on, and my regiment. We’ve had a lot of really good news, so we’re staying focused on that. That’s mainly where most of my energy is going these days. Concentrating on my health and getting back where we need to be which is cancer free. In the meantime, all around me, we’ve got these moving parts which is exciting.

Jen: When we found out about this diagnosis, it was clearly heartbreaking. There’s so much gravity and weight that is given to you when you hear something like sickness, or death, or the potential of what that could mean. Upon hearing the news, within a few hours, our second thought was that Staplehouse is never gonna happen. Then you move on and you are realizing the inspiration of the entire city of Atlanta coming together vocally via cards or emails, or financial donations or an event being put on that’s all in support of Ryan and his fight. Then more inspiration comes from a good friend who says, “you should keep your dream alive. You shouldn’t put it on hold. You should make that a motivator.” We thought about it overnight and the next day we said, that’s it. That’s our goal.

From that point, along with treatment and a lot of other stuff, that’s all we’ve been concentrating on. Because of how heartbreaking it was to think our dream could never happen, to be able to have that type of motivation and this kind of repurposing is truly inspiring to look at every day and work towards.

Ryan: It’s important to note that I feel truly fortunate. There are obviously people that find themselves in these circumstances every single day all across the world and haven’t been given the opportunity to be supported and loved and motivated to keep moving forward. I feel really lucky that I have these friends, my family, and all the support that we’ve had around it. I wouldn’t be nearly as far along as I am today, mentally or physically. I feel truly blessed to have this structure around me. Its been great for moving forward with the foundation, which was our first focus. Which is basically to give back. After the Team Hidi event, which we’ve turned into our foundation, which is The Giving Kitchen initiative. Raising funds and drawing attention to those who find themselves in a similar situation as me. Being able to help more people.

Jen: The foundation is the bottom line in the whole big picture, while the focus is StapleHouse. Staplehouse has become this economic thrusting engine that will support a non profit. Staplehouse has become this bigger entity, and taken on a different spirit in that bottom line. Without Staplehouse being here in Atlanta, The Giving Kitchen really can’t thrive. The whole point of having a restaurant that supports a non profit will potentially give that non profit hundreds of thousands of dollars a year, which is giant. Without that steady stream of revenue to go into that non profit we won’t be able to help as many people.

Ryan: Staplehouse the restaurant will be the engine of a car, which is the The Giving Kitchen, which is our ultimate goal to give back.

Jen: So where we’re at now there’s so much detail in between, because we’re looking at 3 different lives here essentially. We’re looking at the lives of just Ryan and Jen, as a personal couple, with Ryan Hidinger going through chemo treatment and what that entails. And that’s a full time gig right there. Trying to rid yourself of cancerous tumors and be healthy. Then you have let’s all open up a restaurant, and lets bring in a total of 7 partners contributing to one main goal. That’s also one full time job. Then with the bottom line of being a non profit, that’s another full time job. There’s a lot of different moving parts and a lot of backstory which brings up to today which can be very confusing. Which is partly why we say all of our focus is on getting Staplehouse open. Fundraising to get Staplehouse open so we can streamline the story and make everyone aware of exactly what’s happening.

Its one day at a time. We’re talking about 3 different stories here because we can talk about the one day at a time perspective with how Ryan’s feeling, and if Ryan’s not feeling well he’s out of commission for the day.

Ryan: But the rest of it can’t stop. It makes it a little bit harder for everyone else that’s on the team.

Jen: And then when he’s having a good day, we’re working non stop on opening up a restaurant, meeting with architects, discussing kitchen plans, fundraising on Indiegogo, and social media schedule…

Ryan: I will say we’re super excited about what Staplehouse has turned into. The original goal was this mom and pop restaurant with Jen and I running it and while we had great aspirations for that restaurant, what its turned into now is just something so much more. Something that will be more special for the city, and for the partners and the people involved to be able to give back. We’re excited that we’re being joined by Ryan Smith and Kara Hidinger, my sister, who are engaged. Its really awesome that its become a family affair. On a daily basis it will be a family running it.
You have a bad day, which happens a lot, but then you look around and you see what’s going on around you and the energy and effort everybody’s putting into this project and me getting healthy and moving forward. Its a huge pick me up, a huge motivator for me to push myself and keep going. Push through the hard times to get to the good stuff.

Jen: When you look back and you hear a few doctors tell you their opinion on how long you have to live, its frustrating. That’s one thing I will tell anyone that gets sick. Trust your gut, seek as many opinions as possible and only move forward with a doctor or a team that you feel has your back and is like your family. That’s one of the things we found with the cancer treatment center where Ryan is being treated. They are the most amazing facility. They laugh with us, they cry with us. They visit our events. The entire team was at two of our events. Which is unheard of. Doctors just don’t do that. If we had just went with our first opinion, the first doctor we spoke to, Ryan might not be here.

Ryan: I don’t think people realize, what happens to me, part of it is in my hands, and part of it is unknown. You never know what’s gonna happen but you have to believe that you can get better. You have to believe that you can beat it, or it will take over. A big part of treatment with any disease, any sickness, anything you come across that’s bad, its mental. There’s a bit mental chunk of it that could dictate your success rate. I believe that I’ll get better. And I believe that what we’re doing is right for me right now, just like I believe this restaurant, and the foundation are the right path. This is the reason we’re here. This is the reason I’m here. To create this. Whether I’m here for 6 months or I get 50 more years. This project needs to move forward so that forever there’s something to help people that find themselves in a situation similar to mine.

Jason Travis
posts.excerpt: Last time we met up with the Hidingers, we talked about their farm-to-table supper club,…

posts.title: TBW Books
posts.content:
Paul Schiek was the kind of kid who skipped school only to end up at the library. He seemed to figure out early on that the most direct path to whatever he was after didn’t necessarily lie along the most conventional route. In 2005 what he was after was a singular way to display his photographs for his art college senior show. He hit upon the idea of displaying them in a book, but as an unknown art student he didn’t have the resources or cachet to merit his own monograph. So he simply decided to use what materials he could access and set out to create “something like a book.” “I called it a book,” he says, “but really I was just pushing the idea of a book.”

Good By Angels, Paul’s first book, was constructed of twenty postcards. He got a good deal on the postcards and bought enough to make 500 copies of his book. He was already thinking beyond his senior project. “I saw them as 500 opportunities to expose myself.” He had the cards scored a quarter inch from the edge to create a break and a spine, collated them, and had them bound. Then he rubber-stamped the covers by hand. With this first publication he created his calling card. In the process he had become a publisher.

Schiek’s one-man publishing company, TBW Books, is singular for its focus, its process and its product. TBW publishes only limited edition photography books by established artists and up-and-coming talents. Until he began working with a high-end printer and bindery in 2012, Schiek’s do-it-yourself, learn-on-the-fly approach to assembling his books changed little since that first experiment with Good By Angels. Ever improvising and resistant to convention, through TBW Books Schiek produces books and sets, always handmade in Oakland, that are literally one-of-a-kind.

Seventeen years after the Wisconsin teenager wandered into his small-town travel agency and asked for a ticket to California – anywhere in California – he looks every inch an Oakland artist: earnest, mellow, industrious, tough. In his no-nonsense work clothes he could just as easily have come from a construction site or written a poem about a construction site. Still, he retains a self-consciousness about the artist label that may be a remnant of a small-town work ethic that doesn’t accommodate the purely intellectual or aesthetic as “work.” “I like participating in labor, not to the extent that that’s only what I want to do, but when I only participate in being an artist – being ‘no, this is how I feel, man’ – and trying to have normal people in the world take me seriously, I’m embarrassed. So I can’t just do one or the other; I have to have both.” Whether overcompensation or simply unbridled joy for staying in motion, Schiek can’t resist complementing his roles as photographer and curator with those of craftsman, laborer, gopher, and tinker.

If Schiek’s production process – a sort of reverse-engineering with materials of opportunity – is truly his own, so is his marketing philosophy. He discarded any notion of catering to a large, generalized market and made TBW Books a specialty publisher from the outset. “I don’t need to sell 50,000 books. What I want is a thousand people who are rabid about what I do.” Thanks to his small, yet loyal clientele his publications frequently sell out. He repays that loyalty by keeping prices as low as he can. It’s a balancing act between maintaining a low print run and keeping prices down. This is a difficult trick to keep up as his books become more ambitious and production costs increase.

In order to attract an audience, Schiek devised a marketing strategy shaped around pairing well-known artists with up-and-coming talents in alternating volumes, sold collectively as an annual subscription. The featured notable photographers created a draw for the series and every other quarter subscribers were introduced to a new underground artist who benefitted from the exposure. What attracts established photographers to Schiek’s “run & gun” operation? He invests each featured photographer with complete control over the content of their publication. Unconcerned about generating mass appeal for his product, Schiek can afford to disregard the conventional and compel his contributors to take risks. He allows the bigger names the opportunity to experiment in ways that they may not have been able since they were unknowns. “Because these books are meant to exist outside of the general art book market, I want them to be a place of experimentation.”

Schiek is curator, collaborator and craftsman for each product. His influence is particularly felt in the physical product itself. His initial foray into publishing set the tone for the books that would follow. Improvising every step of the way, form necessarily followed function, resulting in TBW’s signature minimalist quality. “Don’t judge a book by its cover,” he quips, could be the design philosophy. He resists displaying any images on his covers and even produced Good By Angels as a black book with black title print. Self-effacing but intriguing, the stripped-down simplicity of the covers gives no hint of their content. As a music lover, Schiek admits that his design instincts owe more to his album collection. “I think about records, basically, how they look and how they feel, and what are my favorite ones and I try to apply that to books.” Not a musician himself, it’s how he expresses himself musically.

TBW’s most remarkable works are its very limited special editions. “This whole idea of a limited edition book is nothing new. Book publishers have always done it. A print, and a book, and a slipcase: a thousand bucks,” Paul says.  But where conventional publishers would be satisfied with standard-issue cardboard, Schiek prefers to craft a complementary work of art. “Craft” is an apt description of how he creates his boxed sets, as he doesn’t rely on routine mass-production processes – unless the routine involves spray paint, sanders and a shop vac. Employing metal, wood, glass, fabric, sometimes the packing material he finds on his print broker’s floor, Schiek dreams up handmade display boxes for the books that act as frames and reliquaries uniquely appropriate for the collected images they contain.  

Dead Men Don’t Look Like Me is a collection of Schiek’s own work – found mug shots of 50s-era inmates that he re-photographed, altering their meaning by re-cropping the originals and highlighting their visible signs of wear. He reimagined the custom box for this book as a work of art in itself, and set out to create something that could actually be displayed on the wall. It was necessary to dream up a way to mount a book-sized box on the wall so that it could be easily removed and opened without using tools or having to deal with a tangle of picture wire or extraneous hardware. His design is elegant in its simplicity. The box set comes with two brackets that are easily mounted to the wall, and two hand-lathed metal pins that are screwed into the sides of the box. There is no other hardware attached to the box, either face is equally clean. The box is cradled in the bracket on its pins against the wall and is simply lifted out to be opened. It can even be hung in reverse.

It’s hard to imagine Schiek’s conceptions taking shape except as the product of someone who can’t stop fidgeting with materials. Naturally, happy accidents play a role in the design process. Helping a friend with his framing business one day, Schiek was cleaning panes of framing glass one after another, assembly-line style. He inadvertently picked up a can of spray paint instead of the spray-on glass cleaner and ruined a pane of glass. Scratching away at the painted glass he got the inspiration for the cover of the Dead Men boxed set – a pair of eyes peering through the scratched-away paint.

A Period of Juvenile Prosperity is a collection of photographs taken by Mike Brodie over the course of years of train-hopping, hitchhiking, and walking across the U.S. An incidental photographer at first – he only began shooting after finding an old Polaroid camera on the road – the shots are full of the rugged, the ragged and the temporal. Designing the special editions for this book is one of Schiek’s current projects. In his workshop he gathers together each of the pieces, like artifacts from a journey, that will draw the sentiments Brodie’s photographs evoke into the three-dimensional. “I was trying to mimic the materials that are in the photos. Most of the photos are of the side of the road, trains, all this metal.” He pulls out a steel frame with deliberately rough welds and explains experiments with rusting that he’s conducting. The frame will hold the contents of the set. The book is jacketed in 75 lb. butcher paper, simple packing material that Schiek found appropriate to the subject matter. It is saturated in deep blue ink and hand-scrawled into the ink are notes from Brodie’s journeys. A scrap of weathered American flag that will bear the colophon – the publication notes – in stamped black ink, accompanies the set along with a steel-mounted, signed print from the collection. Schiek adds an antiqued mirror to the assemblage, like something scavenged off a Missouri Pacific depot men’s room wall. Cold metal and gratifyingly heavy, Schiek gently shakes the assembled box to produce the muffled rattle of the steel print against the frame. “It sounds like industrial America.”


In the digital age, Paul Schiek may be a fortunate anachronism or an unwitting genius – perhaps a bit of both – for putting his faith and creative energy into publishing physical media. He seems to approach his business with the same sort of ingenuity and enthusiasm as a kid building a tree house. And like a kid on his quest he draws help and inspiration from an array of fellow artist/craftsmen. There’s always a friend with a metal shop, or a buddy who’s a framer. There is no hint of the disingenuous in the TBW creative process, so the fact that Schiek is creating treasure from the most humble of materials, and firmly relocating the art of imagery back in the tactile, while so many others in the same time and place are chasing gold in virtual landscapes, sets his work apart by placing it in your hands. Or on your wall.

Joe O’Donnell
Photos by Stephen Zeigler
Video courtesy of TBW Books
posts.excerpt: Paul Schiek was the kind of kid who skipped school only to end up at…

posts.title: Renegade Gardener: Ron Finley
posts.content:
Having identified his South Central Los Angeles neighborhood as a “food desert” – one of many areas devoid of fresh, healthy food – Ron Finley set out to interrupt the cycle of wasting health and wasted resources that such a desert inflicts by transforming his yard into a “food forest.” With his urban gardening initiative, Finley dug up the patchy, unproductive grass covering the sidewalk median in front of his house and replaced it with an abundant garden, replete with all manner of edibles. In the process he unwittingly provoked a mass reconsideration of what it means to be food independent and how best to utilize neglected public space for social good. Finley’s message has ricocheted around the world since he presented it as a TED Talk at the annual convention of big ideas in February. Of course, the appeal of Finley’s insistent message, as he points out, is its simplicity: “Grow your own food.”

An artist and designer, Finley’s initial inspiration for his garden was an appreciation of beauty. “I wanted to beautify my block. And my first thought was smell. I wanted people to come by and smell lavender, and jasmine – I wanted to just bombard people’s senses with smell. That’s basically where it started.” But his artistic impulse was paired with a sense of mission. “I just got tired of the fact that there was no healthy food to be had in this neighborhood. These neighborhoods, they need triage. It’s just like a disaster or war zone or anything else. It has to happen. You have to do it.”

Though unintentional, Finley embraces the role of community activist and finds the most fulfilling aspect of this role to be the receptivity shown to his simple message. As an example, he describes the actions of a kid named David, who credits Finley as the inspiration for his Neighborhood Grocery Store project. The youth constructed his own home garden in Austin, Texas from which he distributes produce – everything from zucchinis to jalapenos – to his neighbors for free. “He sends me these photos. He built planters in his front yard and he’s growing food out of them for his neighborhood. That a kid saw my video and did this, that’s what gets me.”

Significantly, his initiative has had an effect on local ordinances, which had until now prohibited gardening on the city-owned median without a $400 permit. As a result of his efforts and those of like-minded renegade gardeners, new regulations will permit the cultivation of edibles on sidewalk medians. What’s more, the city has promised to dedicate some of its vacant lots to community gardening. The most important result for Finley, though, is the change in perspective among those in his community. People are seizing the initiative to grow their own food. “More people are coming by to see this garden. There are a couple of gardens popping up in the community that I have nothing to do with. The fact that we had a list of volunteers that probably went from 50 to 500 within a month.”

Finley is far from idle, busy promoting his message of food liberation; nonetheless he has expansive plans for his next endeavor – the Ron Finley Project. He envisions a hub of modified shipping container cafes paired with the gardens that will supply them with fresh ingredients. On par with Finley’s notion of “using public space for the public,” each site will serve as a training center for emerging gardeners and cooks while also serving as a center of community enterprise.

Finley is partnering with the Alternative Apparel Grants Project in awarding $1000 to a community initiative to foster gardening and agriculture in Venice. He recognizes Alternative’s values of empowerment, play, and impact as in accord with his own. “Gardens empower people to take over their lives. Play – that’s what you do in the soil. That’s playing in nature.”

HELP OUR GARDENS GROW
Support the cause with our new graphic tees benefiting the Ron Finley Project.

Joe O’Donnell
Photos by Stephen Zeigler
posts.excerpt: Having identified his South Central Los Angeles neighborhood as a “food desert” – one of…

posts.title: Solar Living Center
posts.content:
Hissing up northbound 101 on a wet spring day, the first visible sign of the Real Goods Solar Living Center is a windmill of the rustic American farm variety overlooking an array of gleaming, futuristic blue-black solar panels. A nod to the past situated above a reach toward the future, or the technology of tomorrow supporting the practices of the past? Either interpretation is correct. At the Solar Living Center day-trippers, students, idea entrepreneurs and off-grid homesteaders will all find something to love in the Solar Living Institute’s philosophy of a harmonized low-tech/high concept partnership.

Located in tiny Hopland, 100 miles north of San Francisco in the green valleys of Mendocino’s Coastal Ranges, the Solar Living Center is headquarters for both the nonprofit Solar Living Institute and its commercial-yet-conscious progenitor, Real Goods. Established in 1978 in Willits, CA, Real Goods sold the first retail solar panel in the United States and continues to lead the way in providing solar living products and outfitting customers with anything they need to live remotely and sustainably. In 1991Real Goods founder John Schaeffer started the Institute for Independent Living to move beyond the provisioning of goods to the purveyance of ideas. Rechristened the Solar Living Institute in 1998, it trains professionals in the use of solar technology, offers workshops for sustainable living, hosts field trips for students groups, and through its internship program provides immersive learning experiences for future leaders in sustainability.

Even for those incidental visitors not particularly armed with high-minded intentions, the Center’s shade trees, ponds and Mediterranean orchards offer an inviting stop-off for repowering the soul. The watercourses, living structures and general site design seem whimsical despite being components of a meticulously and ingeniously designed mechanism for low-impact living that maximizes quality of life. The 12-acre site functions as a power source, organic food provider, clean water source, calendar and clock.

Originally a Caltrans debris field containing highway rubble and exactly two trees, over the course of two-and-a-half years Schaeffer and his team of highly regarded architects and designers transformed the twelve-acre site into a verdant model of intentional living. “The site is built around the sun,” explains Sean Spicer, Real Goods’ enthusiastic Director of Operations. And this assertion couldn’t be more literally true. Laid out with careful attention to the sun’s movements, each element is oriented against the four points of the compass; nothing is haphazardly placed. The focal point of the site is the Oasis Fountain, from where wind and sun-pumped water flows through a spiral course whose waterforms serve to aerate and clean the water for irrigating the Center’s organic crops. Eighty percent of the Solar Living Center’s plantings produce edible or otherwise useful crops and are oriented in the site as they would be on the planet in miniature, with a Northern Woods of evergreens situated against the northern perimeter, Mediterranean Chaparral to its south and the Olive Bosque in the southernmost position. The Real Goods Store is a curved, sloping structure that resembles the large side of a chambered nautilus, wrapping around the fountain’s north edge. The fountain and the structures surrounding it form a large solar calendar. A smaller-scale Stonehenge for an observer in its center, architectural markers indicate points of sunrise and sunset for each of the solstices and the equinoxes.

Everything at the Solar Living center serves an educational purpose and the Real Goods Store is no exception. In addition to housing the store’s solar sales center and wide array of goods (from “Bless This Home” garden stones to solar ovens and even an organic wine tasting room), the structure itself is a showcase for responsible design. Employing “passive solar design,” the showroom’s shape, construction materials, and orientation to the sun make conventional heating and cooling systems unnecessary. The thick walls are built of highly insulating straw bales, storing heat in the winter and maintaining a cool interior in the summer. Not only is the store the first commercial strawbale construction, it also initiated the use of remilled wood in its construction twenty years ago, something commonplace today, thanks to techniques developed for this project. The fly ash concrete floors are made from reclaimed coal plant ash mixed with rubble, further enhancing its insulating capabilities. The south-facing windows provide heat in the winter and ample natural light year-round. The sloping ceiling, hemp awnings and opening windows allow for regulating the indoor temperature during the summer heat. Real Goods’ Spicer testifies to the efficiency of the passive solar construction, recounting a day last summer when temps reached 107 degrees outside and customers kept cool in the Store’s 70-degree interior, without the assistance of one electrical system. As for Northern California winters without central heating? “We burned one cord of wood in the wood stove all winter.” And the building did the rest. 

These features may pass unappreciated to the casual visitor, but the showroom’s built-in solar clock is sure to impress even the most jaded and unobservant. Like a scene out of Raiders of the Lost Ark, a construction of prisms inset in the ceiling tracks the sun’s movement across the showroom floor, marking solar noon daily with a white beam while rainbow projections delineate seasonal points of the solar calendar.

Down the hill from the Real Goods Store, at the southern end of the property, stands the Hybrid House, a work in progress and training tool that exemplifies the principles of natural building. Another indication that the old ways can often guide the new, the house is constructed of cob. Cob is an ancient building material composed of straw, earth and water. Inexpensive, readily available, and free of industrial pollutants, it is an amazingly strong and versatile material. While it has the virtue of being fireproof and earthquake resistant, cob is less impervious to water. This is an advantage for low-impact construction and doesn’t pose too much difficulty for maintaining long-term structures since cob wear and tear is so easily repaired. So functional is cob that many of the center’s structures, the pump house and caretaker’s quarters for example, are made of the stuff. The cob structures all wear galvanized tin roofs with broad eaves to protect them from the rain. As with all the materials used in the Hybrid House, the tin is reclaimed. Glass bottles of different colors set directly into the cob let in parti-colored natural light. The combined material costs of the house tally up to only $900.

Solar 2000 – one of Northern California’s largest solar arrays – ranges along the Center’s southern boundary. The most visible feature of the Solar Living Center from the highway, it’s somehow much less dominant when experienced from the grounds. With the handful of SLI vehicles and equipment parked beneath the array’s angled panels they are relatively innocuous, more like carports or naked pergolas. After all they emit no noise, no smoke, and no smell – attributes we frequently associate with power plants. In many ways the array is the heart of the Center, capturing the energy that funds the Solar Living Institute. Solar 2000 was conceived and constructed as a joint project between Real Goods, GPU Solar, Green Mountain Energy and the Solar Living Institute. Its 43,000 single crystal silicon cells deliver 160,000 kWh of energy each year, energy that the Institute sells back to the grid through Green Mountain to fund its education initiatives.

The Solar Living Institute takes its mission of education seriously. The Center is accessible to visitors for free self-guided explorations 362 days out of the year (it’s closed on Christmas, Thanksgiving, and New Year’s Day), and guided tours are available from April through October (donations suggested). It hosts tours geared toward school children as well as more technical tours for professionals led by senior staff. But its mission of education only starts with its tours. SLI offers technical training programs for professionals, and lectures, tours and workshops on a variety of sustainable living topics at locations throughout Northern California. From certification courses in photovoltaic installation to instruction in raising backyard goats and chickens, the Solar Living Institute’s instructional range reflects the value it places on both traditional wisdom and well-conceived technology for sustainable living.

Perhaps the most intensive training that SLI provides is through its internship program. For seven months each year the Center hosts teams of interns and a pair of caretakers who maintain the site, lead tours, host workshops, garden, landscape, assist with marketing efforts and generally lend a hand where they are needed. Living what they learn and learning what they live, interns participate in SLI’s training programs while passing their knowledge on to visitors and implementing their skills at the Center.

Interns live communally onsite in the Intern Village, a cluster of yurt bunkhouses and several cob structures, including a cob-constructed open-air oven and the most wonderfully peculiar of the cob buildings, the shower house. With its dome shape, open air transoms, limed interior walls and tiled floors the shower house calls to mind something both ancient and futuristic, a Flintstones bathroom or Luke Skywalker’s living room on Tatooine.

The SLI Interns are key contributors to the Solar Living Institute’s mission and demonstrate significant commitment during the length of their internships. Many, like this season’s Caretakers, Myryra Grace and Quynton McDonald, bring with them considerable expertise. Living off the grid since she was a child, Myrya has experience in nutrition, animal husbandry and permaculture, while Quynton, with a degree in Renewable Energy, is already well trained in engineering and biofuels. The internship is a significant aspect of the Institute’s training mission. With the breadth of their experience and depth of their training in sustainable living these young people will transmit knowledge while they put what they’ve learned to use in their future professional and personal lives.

Despite nestling right up against the 101, there is little sense of the adjacent busy highway from within the Solar Living grounds. This is due in part to the intentional sound and sight barriers – the strawbale “Great Wall of Hopland,” the earthen berms, the surprisingly tall trees that were saplings just twenty years ago. Luckily it’s a barrier that is not impermeable to ideas or people. The Real Goods Solar Living Center opened its gates on the summer solstice of 1996 with three days of events that attracted 12,000 people. 200,000 continue to visit each year.  Tracing the boundary, Spicer leads the way through the trees to one of his favorite displays, the Memorial Car Grove, where rusted shells of classic American gas guzzlers have become planters for the trees and shrubs growing through them. Weathered to the point that they resemble terra cotta representations of cars, they are literally being devoured by trees.

In its efforts to construct the space thoughtfully, the Solar Living Institute necessarily abandoned convention for a more thoroughgoing form of efficacy. Innovation – doing the commonplace differently – is so much a part of The Solar Living Center’s reason for being that as a work in progress it was continually at odds with codes that weren’t written to accommodate what SLI was doing. Even the automobile planters were a point of contention and to Spicer they are emblematic of the disconnect that once existed, but has since been erased. In the process of creating the Solar Living Center new norms were created. “(SLI) fought like hell to do what we did, but now the government comes to us to learn how to do it.” 

Joe O’Donnell
Photos by Stephen Zeigler
posts.excerpt: Hissing up northbound 101 on a wet spring day, the first visible sign of the…

posts.title: Revive Upholstery by Leland Duck
posts.content:
Leland Duck isn’t your typical upholsterer. He transforms vintage pieces by recovering them in unconventional fabrics such as army canvas tents, vintage Pendleton wool, and waxed canvas. The end result is a wholly original item of furniture and a covetable work of art from Revive Upholstery & Design.

His passion for cars took him to automotive trade school in Wyoming where he grew up. To fill out his schedule he ended up taking an upholstery class on a whim thinking that it would be fun to do the interior of his own car. It came as a surprise that he ended up loving the class so much and he began focusing in on upholstery. He continued to work on cars for a few years but when he moved to Portland he didn’t have the room necessary and started to focus on furniture, which he discovered he likes even more.

Working amongst a group of craftspeople in a lofty space above the Beam and Anchor lifestyle store, which specializes in independent design with a distinctly Northwest aesthetic, Leland is inspired by the creativity around him. You’ll find everyone from soap makers to canoe makers all working under the same roof.

“I think Portland in general is just the best place to be…people support it…I don’t know if I could do what I’m doing anywhere else and make a living off of it. The great thing about it is you can have fun and still pay the bills.”

Sustainability is a big part of what he’s doing, rescuing furniture that might otherwise be destined for the dump and using vintage fabrics, but the attraction to vintage is also aesthetic. Furniture of the past was considered a major investment and built to last generations. By looking to vintage sources it’s possible to find high quality pieces with great bones.

“The older stuff is just made so much better than the new stuff and you can completely customize it instead of just going to the store and buying something right off the shelf.”

Plans for the future include a small line of furniture such as ottomans and throw pillows and more home accessories that can be repeated on a regular basis.

Bria Phillips
posts.excerpt: Leland Duck isn’t your typical upholsterer. He transforms vintage pieces by recovering them in unconventional…

posts.title: See See Motor Coffee Co.
posts.content:
Portland is well-known for its coffee culture and to say that there is a cafe on every corner is just barely an exaggeration. In my own neighborhood alone I have the option of an international cafe where I can watch foreign films and international soccer, an anarchist cafe where I can drink my coffee among photos of revolutionaries, and my personal favorite, See See Motor Coffee Co., Portland’s first motorcycle cafe. 

Although the concept of a motorcycle cafe has its origin in the cafe racer culture of 1960’s Britain, See See is more about creating a welcoming meeting place for everyone. While they do cater to the motorcycle rider with a workshop in back, free air outside, and a store stocked with supplies and classic motorcycle apparel, the cafe draws people from all walks of life who come for the great Stumptown coffee, cool decor, and friendly faces. 

It’s the hub of a growing motorcycle culture in Portland but it’s not cliquish and feels more like one big motorcycle family. On any given day you will see Harley-Davidsons choppers, one-of-a-kind custom bikes, sporty vintage Japanese bikes, and classic British Nortons all parked in a line in front of the cafe. 

Store manager Emily George tells me she’s noticed a major resurgence of motorcycle riding in the past five years and she thinks a lot of that has to do with the fact that in our modern culture fewer and fewer people know how to do things with their hands and to fix things. See See is a place to come and share knowledge and ask for advice, which is a pleasurable social activity in and of itself. She also sees more women getting into riding, which pleases her.

Bria Phillips
posts.excerpt: Portland is well-known for its coffee culture and to say that there is a cafe…

posts.title: L.A.’s Craft and Folk Art Museum
posts.title_plain: L.A.’s Craft and Folk Art Museum
posts.content:
The Craft and Folk Art Museum seems a bit out of place there on Los Angeles’ Museum Row. Not because it’s not a worthy museum; it’s an amazing museum. But because its modest Georgian façade is situated among the hulking Petersen Automotive Museum, the sprawling modern LACMA campus, and looks directly across Wilshire (and apparently several millennia) toward the hapless mastodons stuck in the muck of the La Brea Tar Pits. It’s Pleistocene neighbors notwithstanding, the building calls to mind a nineteenth-century London townhouse rather than the crafty Southern California folk art gallery one would expect. But then, CAFAM’s mission goes far beyond simply rewarding expectations.

“A shrinking world requires an expanded mind,” proclaims CAFAM’s website, and its space seems inspired to this mission. The museum itself is small, but its curators and staff handily utilize the limited square footage to effectively broaden conceptions of craft and folk art while putting them well within reach of its patrons.  It is not a conventional museum; along with objects of aesthetic interest, CAFAM curates concepts and an awareness of how these artifacts continue to affect and be affected by us. This emphasis on social interaction is borne out in the variety of programs, lectures, workshops and performances the museum presents.

The museum’s two upper floors feature rotating exhibitions that have included examinations of everything from tattoo art, ceramic depictions of war, the tarot – and that doesn’t include the numerous solo artist shows. Currently the museum hosts Scratching the Surface: Contemporary Wood Sculpture, which features works from an international roster of nine artists, and Social Fabric, a “fiber-based” art collection by seven contributors that addresses the socio-economic impacts of mass-produced textiles. CAFAM’s exhibits don’t simply highlight aesthetic or historical qualities but the special value of beauty in use.  “Many people view ‘craft’ and ‘folk art’ as unsophisticated art forms embedded in traditional materials or processes with no contemporary relevance or evolution,” explains Holly Jerger, CAFAM’s Director of Public Programs. “CAFAM has the opposite view and exhibits many artists whose work explores traditional processes or materials in new ways and many of these artists also use their work to comment on the social and political issues we are experiencing today.”

The exhibitions, original and inspiring as they are, serve in many ways as an introduction. The heart of CAFAM’s dynamism lies in the multiplicity of programs that promote the involvement of patrons and members of the community. The museum’s exhibitions frequently set the theme for these programs. Currently the Social Fabric exhibition is complemented by performance, workshops and a lecture series of the same name. Developed by Prof. Carole Frances Lung of Cal State Los Angeles’ Department of Art, Fashion and Textile Option, the Social Fabric lecture series is a joint project of the museum and the university. Upcoming lectures will include Christy Matson, whose own hand-woven pieces bridge “the use of technological, immaterial data with physical tangible artifacts,” and contributing artist Allison Smith, who explores craft and the multiple social facets of historical reenactment, or “Living History.”

Even more experiential than the lecture series are CAFAM’s on-site craft workshops, which range from the whimsical to the practical and recently included a crochet class and a “Meet & Make” workshop that utilized remnant materials in the construction of dolls and assorted fabric creatures. “Most people do not have much art making experience (if any), so we can provide a space and resources for them to develop their own creativity,” says Jerger, who currently leads weekly printmaking sessions for artists of all experience levels.

In the guise of her art persona Frau Fiber, Social Fabric’s Carole Frances Lung extends the museum’s interactive offerings exploring the Social Fabric theme. On May 1, in recognition of International Workers’ Day, she hosts a bicycle-powered “Collaborative Mending” event. And on March 23 she led an instructional performance on sewing a shirtwaist blouse, a memorial to the Triangle Shirtwaist factory, whose pioneering ready-to-wear clothes freed women from domestic garment production a century ago, allowing them to enter the workforce.

Not content to limit interaction to its Museum Row patrons, CAFAM conceived the Folk Art Everywhere project, a social outreach program that has become the primary means by which the museum has expanded its physical range. As FAE Project Manager Sonny Abegaze explains, “the initial motivation behind FAE was to take art outside of the traditional museum setting and into spaces where people naturally gather – restaurants, veterans’ centers, grocery stores.” In this way Folk Art Everywhere is able to demonstrate craft and folk art’s “contemporary manifestations,” including workshops for graffiti lettering, tamale making, capoeira, or creating a ‘zine. In June Folk Art Everywhere will be presenting a DIY radio workshop in conjunction with nonprofit web radio collective dublab. “Everywhere,” in this case, means literally anywhere in LA County, as FAE leads neighborhood walking tours as well; come May, Folk Art Everywhere will be leading patrons through Chinatown. And of course, everywhere includes the museum itself, where FAE hosted a free summer concert series last year.

The Craft and Folk Art Museum is the inspiration of influential Los Angeles artist and humanist Edith Wyle. The globetrotting Wyle had the ear of artists, collectors and politicians alike and was pioneering in her efforts to cultivate public involvement in the arts and in promoting the work of traditional artisans.  Wyle founded the Egg & the Eye restaurant and gallery in CAFAM’s current location in 1965 – the same year LACMA opened on the Miracle Mile. Museum Row literally developed around the distinctive little gallery as the Petersen, the Page and the A&D Museums followed. The gallery became a nonprofit museum in 1973 and was rechristened the Craft and Folk Art Museum.

While CAFAM’s boundary-breaking exhibits and interactive programs are reason enough to visit, the museum has an added enticement in its Shop@CAFAM. The toy box hidden in the craftsman’s studio, there are no guilty pleasures here. Each item for sale is handmade and Fair Trade, produced locally or by artists spanning the globe. “If it were mass produced in a factory I would not bring them in the shop,” asserts the CAFAM store’s Global Merchant Yuko Makuuchi. These truly one-of-a-kind treasures include authentic, traditionally crafted items, such as hand-woven baskets from Indonesia or pieces crafted by the exhibiting artists themselves, allowing patrons to actually take home exhibitors’ art. The shop’s stock is a constantly revolving exhibition that directly benefits the local artists and global craftspeople who create these pieces. A draw in itself, the shop is a Los Angeles Magazine Best of LA Winner for Best Global Goods of 2012. When you need Peruvian Fair Trade 100% cotton finger puppets or a Gary Steinborn Buddha Cat sculpture from Venice Clay (two of the hottest recent items), the Shop@CAFAM is the place to go.

Despite the distinctive exhibitions, doll-making workshops, and finger puppets, the Craft and Folk Art Museum does have a more subversive side. It harbors an art collective of “guerilla knitters” known as Yarn Bombing Los Angeles. YBLA’s yarn bombers use knittable fiber instead of paint to challenge conventional conceptions of urban street art, intermingling the notions of domesticity and utility that crochet evoke with those of the unsanctioned underground associated with graffiti. The results may include power poles, trees or entire structures sporting what appear to be their own spring sweaters. More explicit textual messaging comes in the form of YBLA’s Urban Letters projects, which employ “tags” of yarn lettering. The results are as capricious and comical as they are provocative. In addition to hosting YBLA’s monthly “stitch n’ bitch” meetings, CAFAM will literally become ground zero for the collective’s latest “bombing,” which will involve covering the museum building in individually crocheted squares.

Given its multi-dimensional nature – workshops, lectures – and its off-site expansiveness, CAFAM is more a point of departure than a single location. As it approaches the half-century milestone, the Craft and Folk Art Museum retains its remarkable degree of relevance by remaining dynamic. It consistently acts as a social as well as artistic hub, at the same time providing a venue for emerging artists that larger, more risk-averse museums cannot accommodate. “CAFAM can invest in emerging artists, artists of color, women and social practice artists because we are smaller and more independent,” adds CAFAM Executive Director Suzanne Isken. “Without CAFAM, craft and folk art would not have presence in LA.”

Joe O’Donnell
Photos by Stephen Zeigler
posts.excerpt: The Craft and Folk Art Museum seems a bit out of place there on Los…

posts.title: Pucker up for Drinking Vinegars
posts.content:
A wrinkled nose is the response a lot of people give when they first hear of drinking vinegars.

Andy Ricker, creator of Pok Pok Som drinking vinegars, says people’s initial response to the concept of drinking vinegars “runs the gamut from enthusiastic curiosity to outright disgust, but we can usually win people over if we can get them to taste it.”

Portland, Oregon seems to be at the center of a resurgence of this unusual drink. In fact, drinking vinegars have been a part of many cultures for years. In China and Japan they are hugely popular and have a history going back to the samurais where the beverage was thought to fortify warriors for battle. In the middle east Sekanjabin made with vinegar, sugar, and mint has been enjoyed as a refreshing beverage since ancient times. And we have our own tradition of drinking vinegars here in the US going back to colonial times, something adopted from British sailors, where fruit harvests were preserved in vinegar to make a drink called a shrub.

Somehow the tradition nearly disappeared but seems to be making a come-back. Part of the new interest is because of purported health benefits (just google apple cider vinegar + health and you will see scores of results), but even more enthusiasm seems to be coming from people who have discovered that drinking vinegars make a delicious soda when mixed with sparkling water or as a mixer for cocktails.

In Portland we currently have 4 commercial drinking vinegar companies. Blossom Vinegars has been making a plethora of flavored vinegars and selling them at the Farmer’s Market and just recently branched out into drinking vinegars. Genki-Su, which launched into production after a successful Kickstarter campaign, is making Japanese-style drinking vinegars. Sage and Sea Farms takes a locavore approach, sourcing seasonal ingredients such as quince and marionberries from local farms. The most prominent of the drinking vinegar companies is Pok Pok Som which now has national distribution.

The SE Asian themed restaurant Pok Pok began serving vinegars in-house to compliment their food and in 2011 began bottling them and selling wholesale. With flavors like tamarind and pomegranate, the vinegars make a complex and exciting soda or can be used in cocktails.

Pok Pok Som is also branching out beyond fruit to include vegetable and herbal drinking vinegars such as celery (soon to be a retail flavor) and Thai basil. “I think herbs and aromatics are the next logical step from fruit based vinegars” says Ricker.

Bria Phillips
posts.excerpt: A wrinkled nose is the response a lot of people give when they first hear…
